    ', "
  I have a combi boiler with an internet-enabled control (Hive 1?) but it doesn't get all features of Hive. Upgrading to Hive 2 is relative easy on the hardware part. However, you still need to swap out the hub, receiver and thermostat as British Gas has changed everything.", 'My old receiver is a British Gas WR1 which has a compatible backplate with the new Hive receiver. Just power off, take out the old receiver, and put the new one onto the old backplate. That was easy.', 'The new Hive 2 thermostat is also super easy to set up.', 'Changing the hub takes some effort. First, the new Hive hub takes a while to get to the flashing amber light. The green light must have flashed for 5-10 minutes. Just be patient. However, the really trouble is linking the new Hub to the Hive app/account. There is no easy way to unlink the old nano hub from my existing Hive account, and thus no way to input the new hub ID. I have to phone Hive technical support to do the swap over. Basically they removed the old hub from my account and that initiates the Hive app to ask for the new hub ID. Hive could have made this easier! The support line works 7 days until 9:00pm, which is good. But I still waited > 11 min to get someone on the phone.', 'One warning on Google Home integration: Although Google Home claims to work with Hive, the integration is buggy. "Turn heating off" leaves the Hive thermostat in "schedule", not off, but sets the target temperature to lowest. "Turn heating on" does nothing: Hive is left in schedule mode, with no change in target temperature. That means heating won't come back on. I chatted with Google Home's support and they confessed that the features are not working yet. How disappointing? *** However ***, IFTTT comes to the rescue. IFTTT can really turn heating between off and schedule. The shame is that you cannot ask Google Home "what is my home temperature".', "In conclusion, the weaknesses above are not with the Hive thermostat. It is either British Gas' or Google's problem. The product is very good.
", '
  
']

  Very Impressed with the hive controller.  It doesn't seem to be as 'smart' as the nest but its very simple to use and install.  (it doesn't sense when there's no one home etc although you can set geo locations so it will send you reminders when you leave the house with the heating on full blast and a compatible motion sensor is available if that's your bag)  A lot of thought seems to have gone into the design and function of this device.  For example the receiver element of the hive can be slotted onto the base plates for many existing boiler controllers which means that no rewiring was required.  Also the hive thermostat is battery powered and needs no wires or external supply.  Merely pick a location and fit the back plate with the enclosed screws to the wall.  The back plate of the thermostat is even designed with holes arranged so that it can be fitted to a standard single gang back box.  The thermostat is simple and intuitive to use as well as being aesthetically pleasing.  The temperature setting dial and buttons give positive, tactile feedback and are precise and solid.  The user interface online and on the mobile is simple and concise and its easy to control the device and set schedules.  I have a combi boiler in the attic with a controller where i could set a schedule and control the boiler in a cupboard up stairs, but didn't have any room thermostats  So my main reason for installing the hive was to provide temperature control of my central heating system rather than relying on the position of the valves on the individual radiators.  Installation was extremely simple,  as mentioned I simply removed the front of the old controller and fitted the new transmitter to the base, plugged the wireless unit into my router and mounted the thermostat on the wall in my living room.  (I just used a couple of command strips initially)  Everything synchronised and updated and then it was just a matter of registering the device online and creating an account.
", '

  A fantastic device and simple enough to install so long as you're competent and careful.", "I've had mine for about two weeks now and am very happy with my purchase. The Hive 2 ticked all the right boxes - the thermostat looks good and is properly wireless (powered by 4 AA batteries) meaning I have the option to put it _anywhere_ in my house, even where there isn't a power socket nearby; the same cannot be said of Nest which was initially on my wish list. While the Nest can work wirelessly, it's for a few hours at most and needs to be positioned near to a socket. Imagining the location of most people's thermostats, I don't think they would want an extension cable and a USB adapter dangling off the wall - that isn't pretty anywhere.", "The installation was not without its troubles - I was replacing an existing wireless thermostat wired in to different terminals than a 240v thermostat in my boiler so I don't mind admitting I asked someone for guidance. If I'm honest (and to make myself feel better), the main reason I had to ask for assistance was because the boiler's wiring diagram wasn't crystal clear. Asking for assistance can be a mine field. My boiler front cover is lined with foam and held on by a single 10mm bolt and two steel clips at the bottom (Vaillant 2013 model) - it is not a complex undertaking to remove it and replace it properly but some gas safe engineers insist on telling you only they are capable of removing and replacing something like this safely. Legally they're correct but replacing a 10mm bolt and two steel clips does not require a degree in mechanical engineering - just know what you're doing and if in doubt, speak to a pro. That said, if you are capable but don't have an existing 240v thermostat or the ability to interpret a wiring diagram, get a pro to do it.", "When you first put batteries in the Thermostat you'll be asked whether you prefer comfort or energy saving, this determines the initial temperatures and schedule but these can be changed easily on the Hive website so don't agonise over the question too much. Once all the hardware is installed, you need to use the little booklet with a scratch off section at the back to get a code to use on the Hive website. This code is entered in to the Hive website at the URL provided in the bookley and then, once registered with your email address, you're on and customising. Get the app for your phone from your respective app store and use the username and password you created when registering on the Hive website to log in to that.", "Shameless plug - if you're a Windows user and know what PowerShell is, I've abstracted the Hive API to allow control of the Hive (and therefore your heating system) using scripting (which you can schedule on a Windows computer of course). I call the project PoSHive and it's on GitHub. You can set the temperature, boost, switch to manual/auto/off and get properties like current temp.
